name: Wireless Scheduling Scoring
description: Scoring template for wireless scheduling patents covering resource allocation, MAC protocols, coexistence, and interference management.
scoringGuidance: This sector covers medium access control, resource scheduling, and interference/coexistence management.
Key differentiators: efficiency gains, latency reduction, fairness, and multi-RAT coexistence.
Look for innovations in OFDMA scheduling, unlicensed band coexistence (LTE-WiFi), and 5G NR scheduling.
contextDescription: Wireless scheduling patents address how wireless resources (time, frequency, spatial) are allocated among users and services. This includes MAC layer protocols, resource block scheduling, coexistence between technologies (e.g., LTE-WiFi-Bluetooth), and interference coordination. These are often standards-adjacent with high SEP potential.

questions.question: Which resource dimension(s) does this scheduling innovation address? Consider: Time-domain (TDMA, slots), frequency-domain (FDMA, subcarriers, channels), spatial-domain (SDMA, beams), or code-domain (CDMA).
questions.reasoningPrompt: Identify resource dimensions. Score higher for multi-dimensional scheduling (8-10) vs single dimension (4-6).

questions.question: How does this scheduling approach improve spectrum utilization? Consider: Higher throughput per Hz, reduced overhead, better spatial reuse, or improved channel utilization.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Describe efficiency gains. Quantify if possible (e.g., X% throughput improvement).

questions.question: Does this patent address coexistence between wireless technologies? Consider: LTE-WiFi coexistence (LAA, LTE-U), WiFi-Bluetooth coordination, or 5G NR unlicensed (NR-U).
questions.reasoningPrompt: Identify coexistence mechanisms. Score 1-2 if single-technology with no coexistence aspect.

questions.question: Does this patent reduce wireless latency? Consider: Fast scheduling decisions, preemptive scheduling, mini-slots, or URLLC (Ultra-Reliable Low-Latency Communication) features.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Describe latency benefits. Score 8-10 for URLLC-class improvements, 5-7 for moderate gains, 1-2 if latency not addressed.

questions.question: Does this patent address fairness among users or QoS differentiation? Consider: Proportional fairness, priority scheduling, service differentiation, or resource guarantees.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Describe fairness or QoS mechanisms. Score 1-2 if not addressed.
